questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient, 4 months postnatal, presents with a painless swelling in front of the neck. She also complains of fatigue, body aches, dry skin, and hair loss for the past 1 week. She tests positive for thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies. Which of the following is the likely thyroid function test pattern observed during the course of this condition?

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone
T4 - Thyroxine
T3 - Triiodothyronine
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing a painless thyroid swelling 4 months after childbirth with positive TPO antibody titre is suggestive of Postpartum thyroiditis which is characterized by an initial thyrotoxic episode, followed by a hypothyroid state and eventually assuming euthyroid levels after. The corresponding thyroid function test levels are seen in the following sequence:

  • ↓TSH and ↑T3,T4 (thyrotoxic episode)
  • ↑TSH and ↓T3,T4  (hypothyroid state)
  • Euthyroid state

Thyroid function test consistes of 3 entities - 

  1. TSH - Thyroid stimulating hormone

  2. T4 - Thyroxine

  3. T3 - Triiodothyronine

TSH is released from the anterior pituitary which acts on thyroid follicles to stimulate the release of T3 and T4. High circulating levels of T4 and T3 decrease the levels of TSH via a negative feedback mechanism. Abnormality in the circulating levels of any of these markers help in identifying the underlying pathology.

It is called "silent thyroiditis", as it is painless. When it occurs 3-6 months after pregnancy, it is termed postpartum thyroiditis. The condition is observed in up to 5% of women and it is 3 times more common in women with Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Typically, patients experience a brief phase of thyrotoxicosis lasting 2-4 weeks, followed by hypothyroidism for 4-12 weeks, and then clinical resolution. Often, only one phase is apparent.

In addition to painless goiter, silent thyroiditis can be distinguished from subacute thyroiditis by a normal ESR value and the presence of thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies.

Severe thyrotoxic symptoms can be managed with a brief course of propranolol, a 20–40 mg dose administered three or four times daily. Thyroxine replacement may be needed for treating the hypothyroid phase but should be withdrawn after 6–9 months, to enable patient recovery.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding postnatal changes in circulation?

choices.text: Septum primum and secundum fuse, closing the ductus arteriosus
Loss of placental circulation closes the ductus venosus
Following cord clamping, the systemic vascular resistance rises
Higher pressure in the left atrium than the right atrium closes the foramen ovale

questions.solution:
Septum primum and septum secundum fuse and close the foramen ovale.

The termination of placental blood flow decreases the volume of blood returning to the right atrium. Left atrial pressure becomes higher than the right atrial pressure, and the foramen ovale gets closed functionally, usually hours after birth. Anatomical closure occurs within a few months to years when the septum primum and secundum become adherent to each other.

Expansion of lungs after the first few breaths causes a drop in pulmonary vascular resistance and an increased flow into the pulmonary vessels. Loss of placental circulation following umbilical clamping causes a sudden increase in systemic vascular resistance. 

The output from the right ventricle now flows entirely into the pulmonary circulation, and because pulmonary vascular resistance is lower than systemic vascular resistance. The shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses and becomes left to right. The high arterial oxygen saturation constricts and closes the ductus arteriosus, which eventually becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Removal of the placenta from the circulation also results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

The main differences between fetal and postnatal circulation are:

  • Placental circulation provides the gas exchange for the fetus, while lungs remain collapsed.
  • Reduced flow of blood to the lungs and thus little pulmonary venous return to the left atrium.
  • Presence of a ductus venosus, which joins the portal vein with the inferior vena cava. It provides a low resistance bypass from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava
  • Foramen ovale enables oxygenated blood (through umbilical veins) to reach the left atrium and ventricle for distribution to the coronaries and the brain
  • The ductus arteriosus allows right ventricular blood to reach the descending aorta since lungs are non-functioning.

  

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: Over the last 3 months,  an adult man has experienced difficulty swallowing with a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat during meals, postprandial vomiting, and a burning sensation in his chest. His symptoms do not improve on taking proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). A histopathological sample from his upper GI endoscopy is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dysphagia, food impaction, non-responsiveness to PPI therapy, along with histopathology showing eosinophilic infiltrates, is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Adult patients with eosinophilic esophagitis present with impaction of food, dysphagia, vomiting, and symptoms of reflux. Eosinophilic esophagitis should be suspected in patients with heartburn that does not improve with PPIs. Children with this condition present with nausea, vomiting, chest/abdominal pain, and intolerance/aversion to food.

These patients are usually atopic and may have associated conditions like atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or moderate peripheral eosinophilia.

The cardinal histological feature is large numbers of intraepithelial eosinophils. Abnormal squamous maturation is also apparent. Other features include eosinophilic microabscesses, eosinophils in superficial layers of squamous mucosa, and lamina propria fibrosis. The histopathological appearance is helpful in differentiating eosinophilic esophagitis from GERD, Crohn's, and other causes of esophagitis.

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis and is shown below-

 

Barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus-

 

Treatment includes dietary restrictions of food allergen and topical/systemic corticosteroids.

Other Options-

Option (B): Crohn's disease of the esophagus is considered in the differential diagnosis of esophagitis and histopathological examination is required to confirm the diagnosis. On microscopy, it shows abundant neutrophils that infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium forming clusters of neutrophils called crypt abscesses. Mucosal architecture is distorted.

Option (C): Reflux esophagitis too can present with heartburn. However, these patients are responsive to PPI treatment (unlike the given scenario). Histopathology showing basal zone hyperplasia and elongation of lamina propria papillae are common. Chronic GERD leads to intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa which is known as Barrett's esophagus.

Option (D): Infectious esophagitis - The most common infectious etiology for esophagitis in debilitated and immunosuppressed patients are herpes simplex virus, cytomegalovirus, and candida esophagitis. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and from the base of the ulcer in cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

  • HSV causes punched out ulcers with cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies on microscopy.
  • CMV causes shallow ulcerations and characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions on microscopy.
  • Candidiasis, in its most advanced form, is characterized by the adherent, gray-white pseudomembranes.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings

HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus

questions.text:
A salesman met with an unfortunate accident that led to him eventually losing his left foot. He has been unable to walk after this incident and so been rendered unemployed. Match the following examples with the corresponding events explaining the concept of disability.
Event Example
1.Disability A. Loss of foot
2. Disease/Disorder B. Cannot Walk
3. Handicap C. Accident
4. Impairment D. Unemployed
questions.solution:
The correctly matched events relating to the given example are as follows:

Event Example
Disease/Disorder Accident
Impairment Loss of foot
Disability Cannot Walk
Handicap Unemployed

The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function". E.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a secondary impairment as well.

The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of impairment, the affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities and hence the person is considered disabled.

According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped.

questions.text: You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area. You remove a Guinea worm from a patient by rolling it over a stick as shown below. The intermediate host of this parasite is also implicated in which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm (Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick. It is transmitted by the cyclops which also serves as the intermediate host for Diphyllobothrium latum/fish tapeworm.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinensis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

Life cycle of Dracunculus medinensis/Gunea worm :

Treatment:

  • No drug cures the infection 
  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • A simple surgical procedure can be done to remove the worm.
  • Topical antibiotics may be used to limit bacterial superinfection

Life cycle of fish tapeworm :

Diphyllobothrium latum requires 3 hosts – definitive host: man; first intermediate host: cyclops; and second intermediate host: cyclops and fish. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

They are known to cause deficiency of vitamin B12 (Bothriocephalus anemia). The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of Vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to Vitamin B12 deficiency. In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurologic sequelae of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Treatment for  Diphyllobothrum latum infection is Praziquantel.

Other options :

Option A: Hymenolepis nana is the only cestode that completes its life cycle in a single host. There is no intermediate host.

Option C: Multiceps multiceps/Taenia Multiceps is a cestode that has dogs as its primary host and sheep and rodents serve as the intermediate hosts.

Option D: Schistosoma haematobium / blood fluke completes its life cycle with freshwater snails are intermediate hosts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely to be associated with formication?
questions.solution:
Formication is a tactile hallucination in which the patient experiences a feeling of insects crawling under the skin, and is not likely to be associated with cannabis.

Formication is known to be associated with :

  • Cocaine use
  • Methamphetamine use
  • Delirium tremens
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Stimulant associated psychotic disorder

When associated with a substance-induced obsessive-compulsive disorder, it can lead to compulsive skin picking.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented with pain and swelling in her knee. Histopathology of the lesion showed a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells seen scattered amidst round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The stroma appeared well vascularized, with bands of fibrous tissue with areas of hemorrhage and collections of foamy macrophages interspersed in between. Which of the following x-rays belongs to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem and characteristic histopathology findings are suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT), or osteoclastoma. The x-ray findings of GCT are seen in Image 2, which shows an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular lesion, with a soap-bubble appearance.

A GCT is typically seen on x-ray as an eccentric, lobulated, lytic lesion with non-sclerotic borders, giving a soap-bubble appearance. GCTs usually have little or no matrix calcification, new bone formation, or periosteal reaction. Tumors that extend into the soft tissues are seen as soft-tissue masses, which may be covered by a thin layer of sclerosis. They are usually located in the epiphysis of the long bone, but may also extend to the metaphysis. If malignant, the tumor appears as a lytic lesion with a sclerosing destructive tumor adjacent to it.

CT imaging estimates cortical bone involvement, and MRI shows an isointense or hypointense lesion on T1-weighted images.

GCTs are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the bone and are characterized by a proliferation of mononuclear cells, with scattered macrophages. They are most commonly seen at 20–45 years of age. GCTs may occasionally be associated with Paget’s disease of bone and focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome).

They are seen in the epiphysis of long bones, more commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. Patients present with pain and a mass. 

Histologically, GCTs consist of a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells, with scattered, round, or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized, with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. Interposed areas of hemorrhage, hemosiderin, and foamy macrophages are seen.

The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

Other options:

Image 1: It shows Brodie's abscess, which is a small cavity in the bone with little or no periosteal reaction, seen in subacute osteomyelitis.

Image 3: It shows multiple osteochondromas around the knee joint. An osteochondroma is a common benign, cartilaginous neoplasm, seen more often in males during adolescent years. Pedunculated osteochondromas typically point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis.

Image 4: It shows osteosarcoma with a sunburst appearance. They appear as ill-defined, bone-forming lesions causing cortical destruction, periosteal reaction, and expansion into the soft tissues. Codman’s triangle may be visualized where new bone forms in response to periosteal elevation.

questions.text: You notice the following finding in a child during the ophthalmology postings of your internship. The child complains of severe pain in the right eye and is crying incessantly.  The basic ophthalmic examination reveals orthophoria and normal ocular movement. The fundus examination in this child reveals fusiform focal arteriolar dilatations and telangiectasias.  Mild sub-retinal exudation is also noticed. Which of the following will be an indication of enucleation in the child?

choices.text: Tumor more than half of retina

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with leukocoria (whitish reflex of the eye) and retinal telangiectasia with sub-retinal exudation is suggestive of Coat's disease and the indication for enucleation in Coat's disease is neovascular glaucoma associated with the painful eye.

One of the close differential diagnoses is retinoblastoma where enucleation is also performed. You may also see retinal detachment and collection of sub-retinal fluid, but most characteristically we will see cottage cheese calcifications and either an exophytic or endophytic growth with some element of proptosis. Two more important points to remember regarding the diagnosis include:

  • Retinal telangiectasia and subretinal exudation are characteristic of Coats disease
  • Coats disease has no positive family history while RB has a strong propensity for inheritance in families. 

Coat's disease:

Coats disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia that is generally of onset in early childhood. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation.

Symptoms:

  • Unilateral visual loss
  • Leukocoria (because of exudative retinal detachment)
  • Strabismus
  • Fundus: fusiform focal arteriolar dilatations and telangiectasia with mild sub-retinal exudation 

Investigations:

  • FFA - FA in mild cases shows early hyper fluorescence of telangiectases and aneurysmal dilatations
  • OCT - assessment of the macula in cooperative older children.

Treatment:

  • Observation in patients with mild disease
  • Laser ablation of points of leakage to prevent progressive exudation
  • Intravitreal triamcinolone
  • Cryotherapy
  • Anti-VEGF therapy
  • Vitre-retinal surgery: For retinal detachment
  • Enucleation: neovascular glaucoma associated with the painful eye

The given image shows complications of Coat's disease like conjunctival hyperaemia, cataract, corneal oedema due to glaucoma.

 

 

Leukokoria or white pupillary reflex warrants immediate ophthalmologic evaluation and is seen in a variety of pathologic conditions including:

  • Congenital Cataract
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Retinopathy of prematurity ( Retrolental fibroplasia)
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
  • Coats Disease
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis

Note:

Signs of glaucoma include:

  • Corneal oedema
  • Corneal and ocular enlargement
  • Conjunctival injection

The image below shows leukocoria. Compare both the eyes.

 

 

The image attached below shows histopathology in an enucleated eye with Coat's disease. You can appreciate total exudative retinal detachment.

 

Retinoblastoma

  • It is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is called glioma retinae.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.
  • It is of 4 types:
    • Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
    • Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
    • Mixed
    • Retinocytoma : Retina may be diffusely infiltrated

Other symptoms:

  • Leukocoria/amaurotic cat's eye reflex, which is a type of peculiar white reflex from the pupil. Leukocoria is the most common presentation.Squint - second most common presentation
  • Cataract
  • Buphthalmos
  • Pseudohypopyon
  • Proptosis

Indications for enucleation [Group E tumor - according to the International Classification of Retinoblastoma (ICRB)]

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina (Option-B)
  • Optic nerve involved (Option-D)
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic pain and stiffness in his hands, knees, and hips. On examination of the hands, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible. His knee x-ray is given below. Which of the following joints is likely to be spared in this condition?

choices.text: Intervertebral joints in the lumbar region

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes on examination and reduced joint space on x-ray is suggestive of osteoarthritis. The wrist joint is likely to be spared in this condition.

Other joints that are usually spared in osteoarthritis are the elbow and ankle joints. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

Clinical signs: 

  • Tenderness and inflammation of the joint
  • Crepitus when the joint is moved
  • Bony swelling
  • Decreased and painful range of movement 
  • Deformity and instability in severe cases
  • Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes - palpable nodules in the DIP and PIP joints, respectively (as shown in the image below).

Characteristic features of OA seen on plain radiographs:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

The image below is an x-ray of osteoarthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: A surgical team plans for liver transplantation in a child. As a part of the evaluation, you are asked to calculate the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score. Which of the following parameters would you not consider for the evaluation of this score?
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh Score or Child-Pugh scoring system. Creatinine is used in the MELD score calculation.

The variables taken into account for the calculation of the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score include serum bilirubin, albumin, prothrombin time, International Normalized ratio, and clinical signs suggestive of the presence of ascites and encephalopathy. 

The Child-Pugh score is a predictor of operative mortality in patients with cirrhosis and esophageal bleeding. It is now used to estimate a patient’s overall prognosis. 

Alternative scores include the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) and Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) models for all patients with chronic liver disease. The MELD score is calculated using serum sodium, serum creatinine, serum total bilirubin, and INR level.

The PELD model for children under 12 years of age, includes both clinical and biochemical factors. It is predictive of disease severity and waiting list mortality in pediatric patients. The PELD score is calculated using the following variables:

  • Albumin (g/dL)
  • Bilirubin (mg/dL)
  • INR
  • Growth failure (based on gender, height, and weight)
  • Age at listing

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension. It is also useful in predicting the surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations performed in cirrhotic patients.

  • Class A = 5–6 points - Well-compensated - 10% mortality
  • Class B = 7–9 points - Decompensated and significant  functional compromise - 30% mortality
  • Class C = 10–15 points - Severerly decompensated - 75-80% mortality

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: You are a molecular biochemist working on genetic elements and the organization of human recombinant chimeric DNA (cDNA). In a sample of extracted DNA element, you determine the percentage of thymine residues to be 22%. What would be the expected percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 28%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species,

Purines = Pyrimidines

Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 22%, therefore adenine is also 22%.

Hence adenine + thymine = 44% and Guanine + cytosine = 56%. 

No of Guanine = No of Cytosine, so the percentage of cytosine = 56/2 = 28%.

Chimeric DNA (also known as recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant.
 
The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:
  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and stem cell therapy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with a cognitive deficit, involuntary hand and finger movements, and muscle incoordination. He was diagnosed with Huntington's chorea. Which brain structure marked in the given image shrinks rapidly in his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Huntington's disease. The caudate nucleus, which is marked "A," shrinks dramatically in Huntington's disease and, if affected, is also a major cause of chorea movements.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in chorea and dementia and which demonstrates anticipation. The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle. Commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decade of life; motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia.

Markings:

A - Caudate nucleus

B - Thalamus

C - Globus pallidus

D - Putamen

The above image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady with 30 weeks of pregnancy having an obstetric index of G2P1L1 presents to the emergency department with labor pain. A senior resident started the patient on the drug ritodrine to prevent preterm labor. This drug prevents labor by acting as _________

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid after overnight fasting. Which of the following images indicate the most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa (red color indicates the area of injury)?
questions.solution:
As the patient in this scenario consumed acid (corrosive) after overnight fasting (i.e. on an empty stomach), the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus. 

In case of a food-filled stomach, the pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take is known as Magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach, and this is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place, in corrosive injury.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: Used for delivery in a platypelloid pelvis
Most commonly used for rotational delivery
Most commonly used forceps in outlet delivery
It is used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech

questions.solution:
The image shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of breech.

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

It maybe applied electively or when the Mauriceau manoeuvre cannot be accomplished easily.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient needs to undergo cataract surgery. Before initiating the surgery, the following procedure is performed. What is the most common complication seen in the procedure?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in the procedure of retrobulbar block is retrobulbar haemorrhage.

The image shown above depicts the technique of retrobulbar block which is a regional anaesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery. It involves the injection of a local anaesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the middle and lateral one-third of the orbit.

Related Pearl: Complications and contraindications of retrobulbar block

Complications:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication)
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • Proptosis
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Optic nerve atrophy
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Trigeminal nerve block
  • Respiratory arrest
  • Acute neurogenic pulmonary edema (rarely)

Contraindications:

  • Bleeding disorders (because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage)
  • High myopia (if the axial length is greater than 25 mm, then sclera would be thin which could increase the risk of globe perforation)
  • Open eye injury or penetrating eye injury: injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient who had a myocardial infarction has a characteristic finding of Beau's line. Which of the following images accurately depict that finding?
questions.solution:
Image B shows Beau’s line, which are transverse grooves that are present on the nail and may be full or partial thickness through the nail. Transverse grooves may occur due to trauma, inflammation or neurological event, reflecting an acute systemic event (like MI, measles, mumps or pneumonia)

Other options :

  • Image A - Terry's Nails
  • Image C - Mees Lines
  • Image D - Lindsay's Nails

 

Terry's nails are a type of apparent leukonychia of nearly the entire nail, obliteration of the lunula, and a narrow band of normal, pink nail bed at the distal border.

Leukonychia striata also called as Mees lines or Aldrich–Mees lines which appear after an episode of poisoning with arsenic, thallium, or other heavy metals, and can also appear if the subject is suffering from renal failure.

Lindsay's nails, also known as Half and half nails show the proximal portion of the nail white and the distal half red, pink, or brown, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. It is a rare but special clinical finding seen in chronic renal failure with a prevalence of 15-50%. It can also be seen in yellow nail syndrome, Crohn's disease, Kawasaki's disease, Behcet's disease, cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism, zinc deficiency, citrullinemia, pellagra, HIV infection, and even in healthy persons.

questions.text: Centor criteria/score is used for the diagnosis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Centor criteria are used to identify the likelihood of Group A Streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis.

They include the following:

  • Absence of cough (1 point)
  • Tonsillar exudate (1 point)
  • Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (1 point)
  • Fever (1 point)

A score of

  • 0-1 - GAS infection unlikely
  • 4 - likely

In adults, the positive predictive value of these criteria is around 40% if 3 criteria are met and about 50% if 4 criteria are met.

Mnemonic

C- Cough not present

E- Exudates

N- Nodes

T- Temperature

(OR)

Other diagnostic Methods

  • Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal rapid antigen detection test (preferred diagnostic method in emergency settings)
  • Throat culture (criterion standard for diagnosis of GAS infection [90-99% sensitive]).
